document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of the genus Ocychinus (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of the genus Ocychinus (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) from China

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Biology, Shanghai Normal University, 100 Guilin Road, 1 Educational Building 323 Room, Shanghai, 200234, P. R. China E-mail: staphylinidae @ shnu. edu. cn
Department of Biology, Shanghai Normal University, 100 Guilin Road, 1 Educational Building 323 Room, Shanghai, 200234, P. R. China E-mail: staphylinidae @ shnu. edu. cn

subSubSection.paragraph:
The key is based on species descriptions in literature and the photos of
O. caeruleatus
taken from SHNU collection and 12 species taken from Dr. Aleš Smetana’s collection by the second author in 2012.

paragraph.keyLead: 1 Head and pronotum with strong metallic tint, interstices densely reticulated throughout; underside of aedeagal paramere with sensory peg setae..................................................................................... 2

- Head and pronotum without metallic tint, interstices smooth, rarely with partial portions indistinctly microsculptured or reticulated; underside of aedeagal paramere with/without sensory peg setae............................................ 3

2 Larger species, FL: 9.1 mm ; head with posterior angles less rounded ( Fig. 42 ); TL/EYL: 2.41; many large punctures on pronotum ( Fig. 42 ); abdominal tergites with punctation denser ( Fig. 44 )................................
O. motuoensis
sp. n.

- Smaller species, FL: 6.7–7.1 mm ; head with posterior angles more rounded ( Fig. 43 ); TL/EYL: 1.46–1.73; few large punctures on pronotum ( Fig. 43 ); abdominal tergites with punctation sparser ( Fig. 45 ).........................
O. smetanai
sp. n.

3 Abdominal tergites VI and VII each with golden tomentose patch at middle; underside of aedeagal paramere with sensory peg setae............................................................................................... 4

- Abdominal tergites VI and VII without golden tomentose patch at middle; underside of aedeagal paramere without sensory peg setae............................................................................................... 6

4 Head ( Fig. 46 ) with punctation unevenly spread, very sparse on vertex and becoming denser and coarser laterad and posteriad; pronotum ( Fig. 46 ) with punctation quite fine, interstices distinctly wider than the diameter of punctures and appearing polished; pronotum with poorly defined impunctate midline.......................................
O. huanghaoi
sp. n.

5 Legs reddish. Habitus: Fig 15 . Aedeagus: Figs 3, 4 in Smetana (2010) . China ( Sichuan )......
O. bohemorum Smetana, 2010

7 Elytra distinctly shorter than wide, abdominal tergite VII without apical membranous fringe; legs reddish. Habitus: Fig 5 in Smetana (2014) . Male unknown. Eastern Nepal .......................................
O. schneideri Smetana, 2014

- Elytra distinctly longer than wide, abdominal tergite VII with apical membranous fringe; legs black with somewhat paler tarsi ................................................................................................... 8

8 Disc of head with simple punctation, coarser punctures presented only on lateral portion. Habitus: Fig 20 . Aedeagus: Figs 50, 51 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Xizang )....................................................
O. yeti ( Dvořák, 2000 )

9 Head 1.2 times wider than long with rounded hind angles; disc of pronotum without microsculpture, though rudimentary microsculpture gradually appearing toward anterior and both lateral portions of pronotum............................. 10

- Head 1.1 times wider than long with obtuse hind angles; disc of pronotum with fine and dense microsculpture. Aedeagus: Figs 56, 57 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Yunnan )............................................
O. capitalis Smetana, 2003

10 Smaller species, BL= 12 mm . Habitus: Figs 7, 8. Male unknown. China ( Yunnan )............
O. caeruleatus Smetana, 2014

- Larger species, BL= 15–16 mm , Disc of pronotum with fine and dense microsculpture. Habitus: Fig 9 . Aedeagus: Figs 52–54 in Smetana, 2003 . China ( Xizang ).....................................................
O. tibetanus Smetana, 2003

11 Head and pronotum with interstices distinctly smaller than the diameter of larger punctures and thus surface of head and pronotum appearing dull................................................................................. 12

- Head and pronotum with interstices distinctly larger than the diameter of punctures and thus surface of head and pronotum appearing polished..................................................................................... 13

12 Disc of head and pronotum ( Fig. 48 ) with punctation deep and dense. Habitus: Fig 11 . Aedeagus: Figs 86–88 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Sichuan )........................................................
O. meridionalis Smetana, 2003

- Disc of head and pronotum ( Fig. 49 ) with punctation relatively shallow and relatively sparse. Habitus: Fig 12 . Aedeagus: Figs 93, 94 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Yunnan )...........................................
O. monticola Smetana, 2003

14 Pronotum longer than wide; abdominal tergite II densely punctate. Habitus: Fig 19 . Aedeagus: Figs 78–80 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Xizang )...............................................................
O. businskorum Smetana, 2003

- Pronotum as long as wide; abdominal tergite II with scattered punctures on apical half. Habitus: Fig 13 . Aedeagus: Figs 58–60 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Xizang )................................................
O. xizangensis Smetana, 2003

15 Pronotum longer than wide; elytra with lateral sides parallel. Habitus: Fig 10 . Aedeagus: Figs 8, 9 in Smetana (2006) . China ( Sichuan )..........................................................................
O. frater Smetana, 2008
- Pronotum as long as wide; elytra with lateral sides divergent apicad............................................ 16

16 Aedeagus with apical portion of median lobe and paramere symmetrical. Habitus: Fig 16 . Aedeagus: Figs 69, 70 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Sichuan )........................................................
O. paramerosus Smetana, 2003
- Aedeagus with apical portion of median lobe and/or paramere distinctly asymmetrical.............................. 17

17 Paramere slender, gradually narrowed apicad; median lobe with apical portion pointed apicad. Habitus: Fig 14 . Aedeagus: Figs 64–66 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Sichuan ).........................................
O. sichuanensis Smetana, 2003

- Paramere robust, distinctly dilated in subapical portion; median lobe with apical portion hook-like, pointed laterad. Habitus: Fig 18 . Aedeagus: Figs 73–75 in Smetana (2003) . China ( Sichuan )..............................
O. kalabi Smetana, 2003
